messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] NBTHK shinsa
messages.msgSnippet: Sugiyama died some years ago. ... From: Ron Hartmann  Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] NBTHK shinsa To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com Date:
messages.messageBody:
Sugiyama died some years ago.



--- On Thu, 9/16/10, Ron Hartmann <swords@...> wrote:

From: Ron Hartmann <swords@...>
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] NBTHK shinsa
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thursday, September 16, 2010, 11:50 AM







Â 









Bob -



Sugiyama does not handle things anymore, at least not directly. I've always used Bob Benson as agent but understand Robert Hughs also does this service. I'm sure there are others that people use, too.



As for shinsa results, of course a fully polished sword will allow for a more reliable judgement by the team, but a sword just a little out of full polish would probably work okay. The judges have to be able to see and read the sword's characteristics, so if that is mostly hidden, well, they can't see behind what's hidden. If there is a signature, I guess they would paper it based on that, but I'd say condition needs to be reasonably good.



Ron

STL

----- Original Message -----

From: Bob Elder

To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com

Sent: Thursday, September 16, 2010 10:39 AM

Subject: [nihontostudy] NBTHK shinsa



Been awhile since I sent a sword to Japan for advice at the NBTHK as to whether

a sword will shinsa well, before polishing. I used to go thru Oscar, Mr.

Sugiyama. Anyway, who handles this these days. BobElder www.orlandotaikai.com

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Question on mineral oil
messages.msgSnippet: ... Excellent, ta. We have a good engineering supplies store in town, I ll head there for the light machine oil. And thinking about it, you are right in that
messages.messageBody:
On 17/09/2010 6:06 a.m., sigp210 wrote:
> Just get a light machine oil, of the type sold for sewing machines or
> gun oil without additives.

Excellent, ta. We have a good engineering supplies store in town, I'll
head there for the light machine oil.

And thinking about it, you are right in that I'm using too much with
these gun wipes. I should have figured that out myself.

Thanks Brian for the help.

Regards
Matt

messages.subject: Re: Question on mineral oil
messages.msgSnippet: Just get a light machine oil, of the type sold for sewing machines or gun oil without additives. Not too difficult to source. Light machine oil is fine. Choji
messages.messageBody:
Just get a light machine oil, of the type sold for sewing machines or gun oil without additives.
Not too difficult to source. Light machine oil is fine. Choji oil isn't pure oil of cloves...it is light machine oil with a few drops of clove oil for scent. Don't use pure clove oil.
If you are getting too much of a sheen, you are using too much. A few drops on the appropriate tissue, wipe over lightly a few times, and store. You shouldn't be coating the blade.

Brian

> don't understand what there is to appreciate.

> Looking on the web I found several references to using mineral oil (not
> stocked in NZ pharmacies) or gun oil.
>
> After a visit to the local gun ship, I walked out with Remington "Rem
> Oil Wipes". But I'm not happy with the results, possibly caused by the
> additives in the wipes like teflon & who knows what else.
>
> The polished surface of blade, whilst not exactly dulled, no longer
> shows Takano san's hada as well as it did. Additionally I now have that
> multicoloured oily sheen over the surface, but that may be normal?
>
> Mineral Oil. References I've read refer to it as a laxative and finding
> it in your local pharmacy. Obviously we do things different here in
> little ol' New Zealand! But I'm reluctant to purchase anything from the
> hardware store until I know better what it is I'm getting.
>
> Can someone suggest product names or precise details on what mineral oil
> is in the US, so I can find a NZ match.
>
> Thanks for the help.
> Matt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] NBTHK shinsa
messages.msgSnippet: Bob - Sugiyama does not handle things anymore, at least not directly. I ve always used Bob Benson as agent but understand Robert Hughs also does this service.
messages.messageBody:
Bob -

Sugiyama does not handle things anymore, at least not directly. I've always used Bob Benson as agent but understand Robert Hughs also does this service. I'm sure there are others that people use, too.

As for shinsa results, of course a fully polished sword will allow for a more reliable judgement by the team, but a sword just a little out of full polish would probably work okay. The judges have to be able to see and read the sword's characteristics, so if that is mostly hidden, well, they can't see behind what's hidden. If there is a signature, I guess they would paper it based on that, but I'd say condition needs to be reasonably good.

Ron
STL

messages.subject: Question on mineral oil
messages.msgSnippet: I received this week my polished & mounted in a shirasaya, Kogatana from Takano san in Tokyo, made with him in a very enjoyable day working with his forge &
messages.messageBody:
I received this week my polished & mounted in a shirasaya, Kogatana from
Takano san in Tokyo, made with him in a very enjoyable day working with
his forge & filing (a lot of filing!).

Showing it to family & friends, twice I forgot to say "don't touch the
steel" both times I cringed as fingers grabbed it. I can tell you it's
cured me of showing a Japanese blade (albeit a small one) to people whom
don't understand what there is to appreciate.

My question relates to protective oil. Obviously I felt a little urgency
to clean & protect! In NZ we don't have ready access to choji oil.
Looking on the web I found several references to using mineral oil (not
stocked in NZ pharmacies) or gun oil.

After a visit to the local gun ship, I walked out with Remington "Rem
Oil Wipes". But I'm not happy with the results, possibly caused by the
additives in the wipes like teflon & who knows what else.

The polished surface of blade, whilst not exactly dulled, no longer
shows Takano san's hada as well as it did. Additionally I now have that
multicoloured oily sheen over the surface, but that may be normal?

Mineral Oil. References I've read refer to it as a laxative and finding
it in your local pharmacy. Obviously we do things different here in
little ol' New Zealand! But I'm reluctant to purchase anything from the
hardware store until I know better what it is I'm getting.

Can someone suggest product names or precise details on what mineral oil
is in the US, so I can find a NZ match.

Thanks for the help.
Matt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] I wanna know about Fujiwara Masahiro Katana's
messages.msgSnippet: ... In which case its a pity he s cleaned the rust off the tang!
messages.messageBody:
On 9/09/2010 4:01 p.m., Barry Thomas wrote:
>
>
> Close David, close!! This bloke may have read of Kiyomaro's arrangement
> to produce 100 swords for his patron Kubota Sugane around 1840. These
> were called "Buki Ko Ichi Hyaku No Ichi". See page 287 of "The
> Connoisseur's Book of Japanese Swords" by Koukan Nagayama for the
> details. Apparently only one such "Buki Ko" has been found and the
> gentleman who started this thread may believe he has found another...
>
> Regards,
> Barry Thomas.

In which case its a pity he's cleaned the rust off the tang!

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] I wanna know about Fujiwara Masahiro Katana's
messages.msgSnippet: Close David, close!!  This bloke may have read of Kiyomaro s arrangement to produce 100 swords for his patron Kubota Sugane around 1840. These were called
messages.messageBody:
Close David, close!! This bloke may have read of Kiyomaro's arrangement to produce 100 swords for his patron Kubota Sugane around 1840. These were called "Buki Ko Ichi Hyaku No Ichi". See page 287 of "The Connoisseur's Book of Japanese Swords" by Koukan Nagayama for the details. Apparently only one such "Buki Ko" has been found and the gentleman who started this thread may believe he has found another...

Regards,
Barry Thomas.
----- Original Message -----
From: David Zincavage
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, September 09, 2010 11:57 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] I wanna know about Fujiwara Masahiro Katana's


A Japanese subdivision of Winchester was producing Shinshinto katanas tested for sharpness and marked as "one of 100?"

Cheers
Matt

messages.subject: I wanna know about Fujiwara Masahiro Katana's
messages.msgSnippet: My friend is Japanese people has a sword of from his ancestral legacy gift from General TOGO Heihachiro. He want to sale it. (Photos in Album) SPECIFICATIONS:
messages.messageBody:
My friend is Japanese people has a sword of from his ancestral legacy gift from General TOGO Heihachiro. He want to sale it. (Photos in Album)

SPECIFICATIONS:
- Made in THE REIGN OF GO-MIZUNNO, 1624
- Tsuba made from GOLD 22 carat?
- Katana 105 CM?
- Name at Nakago:MASAHIRO FUJIWARA
- Sheath consists from COW LEATHER
- This is ONLY 100 katana in THE WHOLE WORLD?

What you know about this katana?
market price?
Thanks,

Sincerely,
Gamal Pradopo
